awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Development of a rapid assay for the personalized assessment of clot dysfunction due to trauma
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be to create a medical device capable of rapidly guiding treatment to stop bleeding in trauma patients. Trauma can affect the body's ability to form clots to stop bleeding. Of the more than 2 million severe cases of trauma in the U.S., approximately one third will develop a condition: trauma-induced coagulopathy (TIC), which increases mortality 4-fold. TIC can be corrected; however, current tests to identify TIC take too long to effectively guide treatment. This leads to sub-optimal care and increased mortality and morbidity. The current standard-of-care to correct TIC is the transfusion of blood products. A patient should only be transfused if necessary because unnecessary transfusions can lead to complications resulting in longer hospital stays and even death. A rapid assay that can evaluate a trauma patient's coagulation status can help guide treatment of their injuries, resulting in improved standard-of-care that can both save lives and healthcare dollars. Yearly trauma rates unfortunately remain stable, and with an addressable market of more than $400M per year in the U.S., the commercial impact for such an assay is significant.

The proposed project is to develop a rapid assay that provides an individualized assessment of a trauma patient's coagulation status. A significant subset of trauma patients develop impairment to the normal coagulation process as a result of their injuries. Current assays to identify this impairment take too long to effectively guide treatment. Therefore, successful completion of this project will yield a disposable microfluidic card (microcard) that has multiple advantages over current assays, which are slow and non-specific. The microcard will measure clot characteristics currently used by emergency room physicians to guide treatment, but will do so in less than five minutes. This is a critical feature as it quickly guides treatment, meaning that there is time for re-evaluation to determine if treatment is effective. The microcard will also include on-board positive and negative controls that indicate a patient?s individual coagulation profile. This will result in personalized and more accurate treatments that can reduce complications and mortality. The rapid and specific microcard assay will significantly improve care of injured patients while conserving resources and time, ultimately saving money for the U.S. healthcare system.

por.por_cntn:
This SBIR Phase II project focused on research, development, and improving a machine to measure platelet dysfunction to better understand blood coagulation disorders and problems. Platelet cells are the key component of the blood?s ability to coagulate, and they undergo an irreversible process upon being activated wherein they adhere and bind to a site. Once they are there, they undergo a permanent shape change and contract and stabilize themselves against a wound site, and aid in the healing process. However, in cases of heavy trauma, or if someone is on anti-platelet or anti-coagulation medication, platelets can lose their ability to perform this vital action, leading to severe uncontrolled bleeding.

In this project we developed a benchtop machine that can measure platelet dynamics under realistic blood flow conditions, to measure how functional a patient?s platelets are. The machine is designed to flow whole blood across micron scaled sensors which act as force springs. An optical illuminator, and high-resolution camera take images of the sensors every few seconds. The sensors are fluorescently marked, and machine vision and analysis algorithms then deduce how functional the platelets are.

We took a prototype level sensor that was originally constructed on microscope glass slides with a labor-intensive week-long process and optimized all parts of the materials and process. This resulted in an injection molded sensor card, which can be made more in volume, in a shorter amount of time, and at a low enough cost such that the test can be used in a broad scope of clinical applications. We then made process improvements to be able to store the sensors beyond a few weeks in a refrigerator to where they can be stored at the bench-side and have a long shelf life.

The SBIR project also improved the benchtop machine, as we re-engineered the system to be simple to use. The original system required a highly trained user to operate, with subjective adjustments that needed experience to be proficient at. This produced varying degrees of accuracy between users in the hospital setting since experience varied. One of the major achievements of this SBIR was automating the test such that a novice user could reliably run it. To do this, we also improved the optics, cameras, illumination, and added auto-seeking and auto-focusing features to the test. Each of these increases the accuracy and repeatability of the test, and also ensures that the test results can be compared from user to user.

Time is a critical factor in the emergency room, and in situations where bleeding needs to be measured. Existing systems and tests take between 15-45 minutes to generate results, and require reagents and pipetting steps from an operator, which increases the risk for error. The assay developed in this project produces a statistically significant result in as little as 2 minutes and does not need any reagents.

Key outcomes of the study include findings that platelet forces can predict the need for blood transfusion in emergency room trauma patients and those who end up in the ICU. When someone requires a lot of blood product to restore their blood volume or coagulation state, their platelet forces were significantly lower compared to healthy control blood and those who did not have as much trauma injury. Existing blood analysis systems used in hospitals have difficulty detecting this due to the way in which they measure platelet function, which is typically either through blood viscosity or counting how quickly platelets cluster. The machine and sensors developed in this SBIR found that platelet forces are predictive of someone who eventually needed a blood product transfusion. This could improve care by improving the accuracy of transfusions to those that have reduced platelet dysfunction. Conversely, it?s undesirable to transfuse someone who does not need it, as there?s risks associated with administering blood products to someone that does not need it.

We also found that platelet forces are affected by different mechanisms on the surfaces of platelets, such as by commonly prescribed medications. These inhibitors selectively shut down surface pathways on platelet cells and affect how they adhere and generate forces on the sensors. It is therefore possible to optimize platelet medications to each patient and understand if there?s a resistance or sensitivity on that person?s platelets.

In summary, we improved and automated a test machine and its blood sensor cartridge, tested the system in a trauma patient trial, and designed the system to be repeatable and manufacturable at scale. We hope that being able to rapidly measure platelet forces can contribute to more accurate patient care and improved outcomes.
